awd_titl_txt: The Molecular and Fitness Consequences of Spontaneous Mutation Accumulation Under Varying Intensities of Natural Selection
awd_abstract_narration:
Mutation induces genetic variation. Genetic variation, in turn, fuels evolutionary change. Experimental investigations into the rate and fitness effects of spontaneous mutations are central to the study of evolution and biology. Mutation accumulation (MA) experiments have been instrumental in measuring the rate of origin of deleterious mutations. However, the vast majority of MA studies to date are compromised by two major limitations: (i) the use of phenotypic data to indirectly estimate key mutational parameters, and (ii) the use of experimental lines maintained at a single, minimum effective population size. Although population-genetics theory predicts a wide range of fitness consequences for all classes of spontaneous mutations, their distribution of fitness effects remains obscure. Furthermore, the loss or fixation of mutations and their consequences for population fitness additionally depend upon their individual effect and the efficacy of natural selection, the latter being influenced by the population size.  Spontaneous MA lines of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans were evolved in parallel over 400 generations at three varying effective population sizes to manipulate the efficacy of natural selection in different genomic backgrounds. This represents the most ambitious experiment of its kind within any species. The combination of long-term spontaneous MA lines under varying intensities of selection and use of powerful high-throughput genomic techniques will enable unprecedented insights into (i) the rates of origin of diverse mutations, (ii) their differential accumulation under varying regimes of natural selection, and (iii) a framework to assess the interaction between mutation and selection at the molecular level on a genome-wide scale. The aims are to identify all acquired mutations at the mitochondrial and nuclear level, investigate their differential rates of accumulation under varying population sizes and infer their distribution of fitness effects. Phenotypic fitness-assays will quantify the rate of fitness decay at different population sizes and determine the extent to which larger populations are buffered from mutational degradation. By providing a unified account of the consequences of spontaneous mutations at the genetic and phenotypic levels, this research will yield significant insights into the evolutionary process for several different topics, including the genetic basis of variation, the evolutionary dynamics of mutations under the forces of natural selection and genetic drift, and their range of fitness effects. 

Broader Impacts
The experimental lines provide an unprecedented resource to study biological evolution at multiple scales, from phenotype to protein function. The experimental MA lines created as part of this research and the deposition of genome sequences in public databases represent an enormous community resource to be shared with colleagues in the scientific community. In addition to the training projects listed with individual aims, this project will have broad impacts in two areas: academic training/mentorship and public outreach in an environment with a large fraction of underrepresented minorities. Data generated by the research will be (i) disseminated to high school students and the general public via seminars and interactive panel discussions to communicate its evolutionary implications and promote scientific literacy, and (ii) employed in the creation of data sets and mini tutorials for high school students to demystify molecular evolution and introduce them to basic evolutionary computational methods for analyses of genomic sequences. The University of New Mexico is the only research-intensive University that is also Hispanic serving, with two extensive underrepresented student populations comprising Hispanics and Native Americans. This provides a unique opportunity to mentor undergraduate minority students, graduate students and postdocs, and instill in them an appreciation for interdisciplinary research in population-genomics and bioinformatics. Research stemming from this project is expected to greatly enhance our fundamental understanding of the evolutionary process and enable the quantification of several key rate parameters in biology, with implications for all spheres of biology including an understanding of the genetic and phenotypic consequences of maintaining populations at small sizes.

por.por_cntn:
Without genetic variation, some of the basic mechanisms of evolutionary change are incapable of operating. The study of mutations, the major contributor to genetic variation, therefore occupies a central place in evolutionary biology. The majority of spontaneous mutations tend to have detrimental effects on organismal fitness and are rapidly weeded out by stringent selection in the wild. To circumvent this, biologists employ mutation accumulation (MA) experiments, wherein multiple replicate lines descended from a common ancestral individual(s) are maintained in parallel for hundreds of generations at a minimum population size which in turn diminishes the efficacy of selection, thereby enabling the accumulation of mutations within lines and leading to evolutionary divergence among them. We conducted a long-term spontaneous MA experiment in Caenorhabditis elegans at three population sizes (N = 1, 10 and 100 individuals) for >400 generations, representing the most ambitious experiment of its kind within any species. The evolutionary dynamics of mutations at the minimal population size are predicted to be governed by stochastic genetic drift whereas larger population sizes experience increasing intensity of selection. Partnered with high-throughput genome sequencing technology, our research aimed to determine not only the direct empirical estimates of the rates of origin and genomic spectra of multiple classes of mutations in the mitochondrial (mtDNA) and nuclear genomes, but also provide an unprecedented framework to assess the interaction between mutation and selection and infer their average fitness effects. Furthermore, fitness assays were conducted to quantify the rate of fitness decay at different population sizes to determine whether larger populations are buffered from mutational degradation.

Intellectual Merit: Our research made significant fundamental advances in furthering insights into the rates of diverse mutational classes in the mitochondrial and nuclear genomes and their average fitness effects, thereby providing one of the most comprehensive views of the spontaneous mutation process in a particular species. Analyses of the N =1 lines yielded spontaneous rates of origin of different classes of mutations ranging five orders of magnitude (100,000-fold difference) from 10-9 to 10-5 per site per generation (nuclearindel < nuclearbase substitution < mtDNAbase substitution mtDNA indel < nucleargene deletion < nucleargene duplication). We provided the first genome-wide estimate of the nuclear small indel mutation rate for a nematode species, demonstrating a significant deletion-bias as is observed in Drosophila. Furthermore, we provide revised and more nuanced insights into the mtDNA mutation process in this species with respect to the mutational spectrum and deleterious fitness effects of certain mutations in protein-coding genes. Our results offer insights into why adaptation to novel environments is frequently due to gene duplications, given their astronomical rates of origin. Simultaneously, gene duplications and deletions are much more likely to be detrimental than nucleotide substitutions due to the disproportionate effects of gene duplication on gene expression. The frequency of mutations also increased significantly in genomic regions of low recombination. Furthermore, expression of genes in the germline also appears to increase the risk of mutations. Our findings offer greater insights into how physical features of genomes evolve over time due to spontaneous mutations under the influence of both adaptive and nonadaptive evolutionary forces, and is applicable to any level of biological organization including natural populations of species as well as cell lineages within an organism during the progression and growth of tumors. Our fitness assays demonstrated that while extreme bottlenecking (N = 1) leads to substantial decline in fitness due to accumulation of mutations of large negative effects, small to moderate-sized populations (10-100 individuals) can evade this mutational degradation due to selection eradicating these large-effect mutations.

Broader Impacts: This project facilitated the training of 1 MS (female), 3 PhD (male), 1 PhD rotation (female minority) and 2 postdoctoral research fellows (female). It also provided 7 undergraduates (4 female minority; 1 female) valuable research training experience. Other broader impacts of this award include panel service for public events including Darwin Day 2017 at TAMU and GMOs in agriculture (New Mexico), faculty mentor service in several research opportunity programs at UNM for minority students including Maximizing Access to Research Careers (MARC-NIH), Ronald E. McNair Post-Baccalaureate Achievement and Undergraduate Opportunities (UnO- NSF), and member-at-large service representing minority women in STEM disciplines in the Women?s Faculty Network at TAMU. Other broad impacts include multiple national and international presentations by the PI and trainees on the funded research. An aim of this grant was to develop MA lines as a resource for the extended scientific community; these lines have thus far been shared and utilized by six other C. elegans and biological researchers and all genomic and phenotypic datasets have been archived in publicly available repositories. The results of the phenotypic fitness-assays have important implications for conservation biology and the management of small, threatened populations. Lastly, spontaneous mutations are implicated in simple Mendelian and complex genetic disorders in humans with implications for human health.
